[[File:Kashgari map.jpg|thumb|308px|Map from [[Mahmud al-Kashgari]]'s ''Divanu Lughat at-Turk'', showing the 11th century distribution of Turkic tribes]] [[File:Pontic steppe region around 650 AD.png|thumb|300px|The [[Pontic steppe]], c. 650, showing the early territories of the [[Khazars]], [[Bulgars]], and [[Pannonian Avars|Avars]]]] [[File:Khazarfall1.png|thumb|right|300px|[[Europe]], showing the area of main [[Pecheneg]] settlement, c. 1015]] [[File:Seljuk Empire locator map.svg|right|300px|thumb|The [[Great Seljuq Empire]] in 1092, upon the death of [[Malik Shah I]]{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}]] [[File:Premongol-Kipchak.png|thumb|right|300px|[[Cumania]] in Eurasia circa 1200]] '''Turkic migration''' refers to the expansion of the [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] tribes and [[Turkic languages]] into [[Central Asia]], [[Eastern Europe]] and [[West Asia]], mainly between the 6th and 11th centuries. The region of origin of the [[Turkic peoples]] is southern [[Siberia]] ([[North Asia]]) and the northern parts of modern-day [[Xinjiang]], [[Mongolia]] and [[Kazakhstan]].
Identified Turkic tribes were known by the 6th century, and by the 10th century most of Central Asia was settled by Turkic tribes. The [[Seljuq dynasty]] settled in [[Anatolia]] starting in the 11th century, ultimately resulting in permanent Turkic settlement and presence there. Meanwhile, other Turkic tribes either ultimately formed independent nations, such as [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Uzbekistan]] and [[Kazakhstan]], and others now enclaves within other nations, such as [[Chuvashia]], [[Bashkortostan]], [[Tatarstan]], the [[Crimean Tatars]], the [[Uyghurs]] in [[China]], and the [[Sakha Republic]] [[Siberia]].
==Ancestral populations== The earliest documented Turkic peoples appear as nomadic tribes on the plains of the Far East north of the [[Great Wall of China]], which was constructed as a fortified border essentially between [[Han dynasty]] (206 BCE-220 CE) China (though started earlier) and the [[Xiongnu]].
===''Records of the Grand Historian''=== The population ancestral to the Turks is thought to have included the Xiongnu of [[Mongolia]] or along the upper [[Yenisei]] in [[Siberia]] (the area of the contemporary [[Tuvan language]]), known from historical sources. The Han chronicle of the Xiongnu, included in the ''[[Records of the Grand Historian]]'' of the second century BCE, traces a legendary history of them back a thousand years before the Han to a legendary ancestor, [[Chunwei]], a supposed descendant of the Chinese rulers of the [[Xia dynasty]]<ref>{{cite book|first= Qian|last= Sima|author2= Burton Watson |title= Records of the Grand Historian|publisher= Columbia University Press |year= 1993|isbn=0-231-08166-9|pages=129–162}}</ref> (c. 2070 – c. 1600 BCE). Chunwei lived among the "Mountain Barbarians" [[Xianyun]] or Hunzhu. Xianyun and Hunzhu's names may connect them to the Turkic people, who later were said{{by whom|date=February 2015}} to have been iron-workers and to have kept a national shrine in a mountain cave in [[Mongolia]].
Apparently the Xiongnu comprised a number of tribes and geographic groups, not all of which were probably Turkic (considering the later mixed ethnicity). The ''Records of the Grand Historian'' mention the Mianshu, Hunrong and Diyuan west of [[Gansu|Long]]; the Yiqu, Dali, Wiezhi and [[Quyan]] north of the Qi and [[Liang mountains]] and Jing and Qi Rivers; the Forest Barbarians and [[Loufan (people)|Loufan]] north of [[Jin (Chinese state)|Jin]] and the Eastern Barbarians and Mountain Barbarians north of [[Yan (state)|Yan]]. Later the treatise mentions others.
There were apparently many of the latter. At the end of the Xia, about 1569 BCE by the reckoning of the ''Records of the Grand Historian'', the Chinese founded a city, Bin, among the [[Rong people|Rong]] tribe of barbarians. In 1269 the Rong and the Di forced the relocation of Bin. About 1169 BCE the Quanyishi tribe was attacked by the [[Zhou Dynasty]], which in 1159 forced all the barbarians into "the submissive wastes" north of the [[Jing River|Jing]] and [[Luo River (Shaanxi)|Luo]] Rivers. In 969 BCE "King Mu attacked the [[Quanrong]] and brought back with him four white wolves and four white deer ...." The early Turkic peoples believed that [[shamanism|shaman]]s could [[Shapeshifting|shape-shift]] into [[Wolf|wolves]].
In 769 [[Marquess of Shen|Marquis Shen]] of the [[Zhou Dynasty|Zhou]] enlisted the assistance of the Quanrong in rebelling against the emperor You. The barbarians did not then withdraw but took Jiaohuo between the Jing and [[Wei River]]s and from there went marauding into central China, but were driven out. In 704 the Mountain Barbarians marauded through [[Yan (Ten Kingdoms)|Yan]], and in 660 BC attacked the Zhou emperor Xiang in Luo. He had discarded a barbarian queen. The barbarians put another on the throne. They went on plundering until driven out in 656 BC.
Subsequently the Chinese drove out the Di and subordinated all the Xiongnu (temporarily at least). Around 456 BC the Chinese took Dai from them. The Yiqu tribe tried building fortifications but lost them to the Chinese in this period of their expansion. Here the detail of the narrative increases as it deals with the rise of the [[Qin Dynasty]] of 221-206 BCE, which is no doubt mainly historical rather than legendary. The Qin kept the Xiongnu at bay.
===Equestrian pastoralists of the northeast=== <!-- Commented out the following as unverifiable, reliant on obsolete physical anthropology, original research and/or unreferenced: The physical characteristics of populations of speakers of Turkic language stretch across a range as wide as the land they inhabit. The Turkic peoples in Europe look European - with the exception of some [[Crimean Tatars]] and Turkics in the Caucasus ([[Kumyks]], [[Nogays]], etc.) who look European+Northeast Asian, while Turkics in the Middle East resemble the peoples of the Middle East, those in Central Asia mostly look mixed but have mostly northeast Asian features. Turkics in northeast Asia resemble populations in that region. -->In trying to answer questions regarding the "[[Race (classification of human beings)|race]]" of the proto-Turkic speakers, neither [[anthropometric]] nor [[Genetics|genetic]] studies have provided conclusive answers. [[DNA]] analyses find affinities to West Eurasian populations in the west, North East Asian populations in the east, and a mixture of both on a gradient in-between.<ref>{{cite web|first= E.|last= Khusnutdinova|title= POSTER NO: 548: Mitochondrial DNA variety in Turkic and Uralic-speaking people|url= http://hgm2002.hgu.mrc.ac.uk/Abstracts/Publish/WorkshopPosters/WorkshopPoster11/hgm0548.htm|publisher= HGM2002|location= Shanghai|year= 2002|display-authors= etal|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120222145407/http://hgm2002.hgu.mrc.ac.uk/Abstracts/Publish/WorkshopPosters/WorkshopPoster11/hgm0548.htm|archivedate= 2012-02-22|df= }}</ref> These genetic circumstances suggest that the major "racial" changes over this vast region occurred at a major earlier time than spread of Turkic languages; the languages may have evolved among populations that were already mixed.{{Clarify|date=June 2013}}
[[File:Grasslands-menggu.jpg|thumb|left|Grassland in Inner Mongolia]]
Concerning the cultural genesis of the Huns, the ''Cambridge Ancient History of China'' asserts: "Beginning in about the eighth century BC, throughout inner Asia horse-riding pastoral communities appeared, giving origin to warrior societies." These were part of a larger belt of "equestrian pastoral peoples" stretching from the [[Black Sea]] to [[Mongolia]], and known to the Greeks as the [[Scythians]].<ref>{{Cite book | first = Nicola | last = Di Cosmo | editor-last = Loewe | editor-first = Michael | editor2-last = Shaughnessy | editor2-first = Edward L. | contribution = The Northern Frontier in Pre-Imperial China | title = The Cambridge History of Ancient China: From the Origins of Civilization to 221 B.C | year = 1999 | page = 886 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 0-521-47030-7 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> The Scythians in the west were [[Ancient Iranian peoples|Iranian]], speaking one among very many languages ultimately descended from [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]], whose speakers themselves are also hypothesised to have occupied the Pontic-Caspian Steppe, according to the leading theory of [[Proto-Indo-European Urheimat hypotheses|Indo-European origins]], the [[Kurgan hypothesis|Kurgan model]]. The communities of the northern belt north of China, a historically Inner Mongolia region were the Proto-Xiongnu.
===Xiongnu=== {{Further|Han–Xiongnu War}} {{details|Xiongnu}} [[File:Han foreign relations CE 2.jpg|thumb|right|350px|The [[Han Dynasty]] and the [[Xiongnu]]]] [[Qin's campaign against the Xiongnu]] of 215 BCE kept the Xiongnu at bay,<ref>{{cite book|first= Frances|last= Wood|title= The Silk Road: Two Thousand years in the Heart of Asia|year= 2002|publisher= University of California Press|isbn=0-520-23786-2|page=50}}</ref> driving them out of and seizing the Ordos region.<ref>{{cite book | first=Patricia Buckley | last=Ebrey | last2=Walthall | first2=Anne | last3=Palais | first3=James B. | title=East Asia: A cultural, social, and political history | year= 2009 | edition=2nd | publisher=Houghton Mifflin | location=Boston | isbn=978-0-547-00534-8 | page=40}}</ref> Problems re-emerged after the Qin Dynasty. The Xiong-nu attacked [[Shanxi]] of the Han in 201 BCE. [[Emperor Gaozu of Han]] bought them off with [[jade]], [[silk]] and a Chinese wife for the Shanyu, or leader.<ref>{{cite book|first= W. Scott|last= Morton|author2= Charlton M. Lewis |title= China: Its History and Culture: Fourth Edition|publisher= McGraw-Hill Professional |year= 2004|isbn= 0-07-141279-4|page= 52}}</ref> Relations with the Xiongnu continued to be troubled and in 133 BC [[Emperor Wu of Han]] proceeded against them with 300,000 men.<ref>Morton (2004), page 55.</ref> Eighty-one years and fourteen expeditions later in 52 BC the southern Xiongnu surrendered and the northern desisted from raiding. The Han Dynasty military expeditions continued near the frontier of China, in the [[Han–Xiongnu War]], and in 89 AD the Xiongnu state was defeated and soon ended.<ref name=houhanshu>''[[Book of Later Han]]'', vols. [[s:zh:後漢書/卷4|04]], [[s:zh:後漢書/卷19|19]], [[s:zh:後漢書/卷23|23]], [[s:zh:後漢書/卷88|88]], [[s:zh:後漢書/卷89|89]], [[s:zh:後漢書/卷90|90]].</ref><ref name=tongjian> ''[[Zizhi Tongjian]]'', vol. [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷047|47]]. </ref>
One especially severe round of nomadic rebellion in the early 4th century has led to the certain identification of the Xiongnu with the [[Huns]]. A letter (Letter II) written in the ancient [[Sogdian language]] excavated from a Han Dynasty watchtower in 1911 identified the perpetrators of these events as the ''xwn'', "Huns", supporting [[Joseph de Guignes|de Guignes]]' 1758 identification. The equivalence was not without its critics, notably [[Otto J. Maenchen-Helfen]], who argued that ''xwn'' was a general name and could refer to anyone. More recently other evidence was noticed: Zhu Fahu, a monk, translated [[Sanskrit]] ''Hūṇa'' in the ''Tathāgataguhya Sūtra'' and in the ''[[Lalitavistara Sūtra]]'' as "Xiongnu". Vaissière reconstructs the pronunciation as *Xi<sup>w</sup>ong nuo. Moreover, the ''[[Book of Wei]]'' states that the king of the Xiongnu killed the king of [[Sogdia]] and took the country, an event is datable to the time of the Huns, who did exactly that; in short, "... the name of the Huns is a precise referent and not generic."<ref> {{Cite book |last = Vaissière |first = Etienne de la | contribution = The Rise of Sogdian Merchants and the Role of the Huns: The Historical Importance of the Sodgian Ancient Letters | year = 2004 | title = The Silk Road: Trade, travel, War and Faith | editor-last = Whitfield | editor-first = Susan | pages = 22–23 | place = Chicago | publisher = Serindia Publications Inc. | isbn = 1-932476-12-1 |author2-link = Hampson, Translator |editor2-first = Kate |postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref>
==Huns== [[File:Huns empire.png|thumb|300px|The [[Huns#Unified Empire under Attila|Hunnic Empire]] of about AD 450 as seen by European authors. The star marks where the nomadic Huns chose to encamp, the [[Pannonian Basin|Hungarian plain]], a sort of enclave of [[steppe]] country in a mountainous region.]] [[File:Bulgarians and Slavs VI-VII century.png|thumb|300px|The migration of the [[Bulgars]] after the fall of [[Old Great Bulgaria]] in the 7th century.]] ===Identity of the Huns=== {{details|Huns}}
While their actual identity is still debated, the Huns have often been considered a Turkic people, and sometimes associated with the Xiongnu. [[Paulus Orosius|Orosius]] has the Huns riding down upon the [[Ostrogoths]] in the year AD 377 totally by surprise, "long shut off by inaccessible mountains"<ref>{{cite web|author=Orosius|authorlink=Paulus Orosius|title=Historiarum Adversum Paganos Libri VII|publisher=The Latin Library|work=Book VII Section 33.10|url=http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/orosius/orosius7.shtml#33}}</ref> and apparently of hitherto unsuspected existence. Whatever may have been his reasons for making such a statement, he and Goths might have found ample reference to the Huns in the classical geographers, such as [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] and [[Ptolemy]]; in fact, some were already in Europe.<ref>{{cite book|first=Otto J.|last=Maenchen-Helfen|authorlink=Otto J. Maenchen-Helfen|editor=Max Knight|title=The World of the Huns|publisher=The University of California Press|year=1973|pages=444–455}}</ref> The mountains were mythical as the Ostrogoths were located on the Pontic steppe, an easy target for Hunnic cavalry.
While in Europe they incorporated others, such as Goths, Slavs, and [[Alans]].
The Huns were not literate (according to [[Procopius]]<ref name=MH376>Maenchen-Helfen (1973) page 376.</ref>) and left nothing linguistic with which to identify them except their names,<ref name=MH376/> which derive from Germanic, Iranian, Turkic, unknown and a mixture.<ref>Maenchen-Helfen (1973) pages 441–442.</ref> Some, such as Ultinčur and Alpilčur, are like Turkish names ending in -čor, [[Pecheneg]] names in -tzour and [[Kyrgyz people|Kirghiz]] names in -čoro. Names ending in -gur, such as [[Utigurs|Utigur]] and [[Onogurs|Onogur]], and -gir, such as Ultingir, are like Turkish names of the same endings.
One tribe of the Huns called themselves the Acatir (Greek Akatiroi, Latin Acatiri), which [[Wilhelm Tomaschek]] derived from Agac-ari, "forest men",<ref>Maenchen-Helfen (1973) pages 427–428.</ref> reminiscent of the "Forest Barbarians" of the Shi-Ji. The Agaj-eri are mentioned in an AD 1245 Turko-Arabian Dictionary. The name Agac-eri occurred in later history in [[Anatolia]] and [[Khuzistan]](e.g. city of [[Aghajari]]). Maenchen-Helfen rejects this etymology on the grounds that g is not k and there appears to be no linguistic rule to make the connection.<ref>Maenchen-Helfen (1973) page 437.</ref> [[Herodotus]], however, mentions the [[Agathyrsi]], whom Latham connects with some early Acatiri in [[Dacia]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Robert Gordon|last=Latham|authorlink=Robert Gordon Latham|title=The Nationalities of Europe: Volume 2|publisher=Adamant Media Corporation|date=2003 from 1863|isbn=1-4021-8765-3|page=391}}</ref>
[[Jordanes]] places the "most mighty race of the [[Acatziri]], ignorant of agriculture, which lives upon its herds and upon hunting" south of the [[Aesti]] (in part [[Old Prussians|Prussians]]). A number of sources identify the [[Bulgars]] with the Huns.<ref>Maenchen-Helfen (1973) page 432.</ref> Another branch were the Saviri, or [[Sabir people]]. The strongest candidate for a remnant of the speakers of the [[Hunnic language]] are the [[Chuvash people|Chuvash]], who are on or near the location of the [[Volga Bulgars]].
== Göktürks == The end of the Huns as a Eurasian political unity is not known. A token end point for the Huns of the west, perhaps all the Huns, is the fixation of the head of [[Dengizich]], a son of [[Attila]], on a pole at [[Constantinople]] in 469. He had been defeated in [[Thrace]] in that year by [[Anagastes]], a [[Goths|Gothic]] general in the service of the [[Roman Empire]].<ref>Maenchen-Helfen (1973), Page 168.</ref>
Various peoples continued to call themselves Huns even though acting autonomously, such as the [[Sabir people]]. According to the ''Cambridge History of Early Inner Asia'', the last state to call itself Hunnic was the Caucasian Kingdom of the Huns, visited in 682 by an Albanian bishop.<ref>{{cite book|first=Denis|last=Sinor|title=The Cambridge History of Early Inner Asia|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1990|isbn=0-521-24304-1|page=201}}</ref> Many of these peoples were Turkic but meanwhile other coalitions leading to explicitly named Turkic empires had been forming on the original range of the Xiong-nu. Their expansion has been conventionally called the "Turkic migration" but in fact the Turkics had already been "migrating" for some centuries.
===Five Hu=== The early-fourth-century saw a rebellion, with sacking of northern Chinese cities, by the Xiong-nu. However, most of the Xiongnu were later wiped out by the Chinese [[Ran Wei]] state (350–352) after [[Ran Min]]'s cull order following the end of the [[Wei–Jie war]], which annihilated three of the "Five Hu" tribes. In that century some of the Xiong-nu broke away and joined with the Di as the [[Five Barbarians|Five Hu]], or "Five Barbarian Peoples" (Wu Hu 五胡), as the Chinese called them, for purposes of ruling the north of China.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Genesis of East Asia, 221 B.C.-A.D. 907|first=Charles|last=Holcombe|isbn=0-8248-2465-2|year=2001|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|page=114}}</ref> The Five Hu were the [[Xiong-nu]], [[Jie (ethnic group)|Jie]], [[Zhi]], [[Chiang people]] and [[Xianbei]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Buddhist Studies in the People's Republic of China, 1990–1991|first=Michael R.|last=Saso|isbn=0-8248-1363-4|year=1991|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|page=141}}</ref> although different groups of historians and historiographers have their own definitions.{{Clarify|date=February 2016}}
===Rouran and Tie-le=== However, the Chinese name "tie-le", corresponding to "Türük", was used much earlier, around the period when the [[Proto-Mongols|Mongolic]] tribes [[Tuoba]] and [[Rouran]] vied for hegemony over the [[Eurasian steppes|Mongolian steppes]] around the 5th and 6th centuries.
===Tu-jue (Turks)=== The term ''Türk'' or ''Türküt'', corresponding to the Chinese name ''tu-jue'', was first used as an endonym in the [[Orkhon inscriptions]] of the [[Göktürks]] ({{lang-en|'Celestial Turks'}}) of [[Central Asia]]. The first reference to "Turks" (''[[Tujue]]'') appears in Chinese sources of the 6th century. The earliest evidence of [[Turkic languages]] as a separate group comes from the [[Orkhon inscriptions]] of the early 8th century.
The precise date of the initial expansion from the early homeland remains unknown. The first state known as "Turk", giving its name to the many states and peoples afterwards, was that of the [[Göktürks]] (''gök'' = 'blue' or 'celestial', however in this context [[Cardinal directions#Northern Eurasia|"gök" refers to the direction "east"]]. Therefore, Gokturks are the Eastern Turks) in the 6th century. The head of the '''[[Ashina tribe|Ashina]]''' clan led his people from Li-jien (modern [[Zhelaizhai]]) to the [[Rouran]] seeking inclusion in their confederacy and protection from China. His tribe comprised famed metal smiths and was granted land near a mountain quarry that looked like a helmet, from which they got their name 突厥. A century later their power had increased such that they conquered the Rouruan and set about establishing a Göktürk Empire (reference required).
The Turkic family of languages were spoken by [[Bulgars]], Pechenegs, Cumans, Dingling, [[Tiele people|Gaoche]] peoples long before the Göktürk Khanate came into prominence. Many groups speaking 'Turkic' languages never adopted the name "Turk" for their own identity. Among the peoples that came under Göktürk dominance and adopted its political culture and lingua-franca, the name "Turk" wasn't always the preferred identity. In other words, there wasn't a unified movement westward by a culture under one unified ethnic identity, such as that of the Mongol conquest of Eurasia under the [[Chinggisid]] political leadership. Rather, Turkic languages – both peripheral ones like the Bulgar branch and central ones like the Oghuz and Karluk-Chagatay branches – drifted westward by autonomous movements of diverse tribes and migrating traders, soldiers and townspeople, outnumbering and assimilating non-Turkic indigenous peoples along the way, and being partly replaced by other language families that have become prominent in the east, such as Mongolic languages on the Mongolian steppes, Indic languages in India, and [[Persian language|Persian]] in post-Timurid Iran (reference required).
==Uyghurs== [[File:East-Hem 800ad.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Uyghur Khaganate]] in geopolitical context c. AD 800]] Later Turkic peoples include the [[Karluks]] (mainly 8th century), [[Uyghur people|Uyghurs]], [[Kyrgyz people|Kyrgyz]], [[Oghuz Turks|Oghuz]] (or Guz, Uz, Ghuzz, etc.) Turks, and [[Turkmen people|Turkmens]]. As these peoples were founding states in the area between [[Mongolia]] and [[Transoxiana]], they came into contact with Muslims, and most gradually adopted [[Islam]]. However, there were also some other groups of Turkic people who belonged to other religions, including [[Christianity|Christians]], [[Jew]]s (see [[Khazars]]), [[Buddhism|Buddhists]], and [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrians]].
==Turkmens== [[File:11 13th century Asia Minor Turkish Invasions.png|thumbnail|320px|Settlements and regions affected during the first wave of Turkish invasions in Asia Minor (1050-1204).]] While the Karakhanid state remained in this territory until its conquest by [[Genghis Khan]], the Turkmen group of tribes was formed around the core of westward Oghuz. The name "Turkmen" originally simply meant "I am Turk" in the language of the diverse tribes living between the Karakhanid and Samanid states. Thus, the ethnic consciousness among some, but not all Turkic tribes as "Turkmens" in the Islamic era came long after the fall of the non-Muslim Gokturk (and Eastern and Western) Khanates. The name "Turk" in the Islamic era became an identity that grouped Islamized Turkic tribes in contradistinction to Turkic tribes that were not Muslim (that mostly have been referred to as "Tatar"), such as the [[Nestorian Christians|Nestorian]] [[Naimans|Naiman]] (which became a major founding stock for the [[Kazakhs|Muslim Kazakh nation]]) and Buddhist [[Tuvans]]. Thus the ethnonym "Turk" for the diverse Islamized Turkic tribes somehow served the same function as the name "[[Tajik people|Tajik]]" did for the diverse [[Iranian peoples]] who converted to Islam and adopted [[Persian language|Persian]] as their lingua-franca. Both names first and foremost labeled Muslimness, and to a lesser extent, common language and ethnic culture. Long after the departure of the Turkmens from Transoxonia towards the [[Karakum Desert|Karakum]] and [[Caucasus]], consciousness associated with the name "Turk" still remained, as [[Chagatai Khanate|Chagatay]] and [[Timurid Empire|Timurid]] period Central Asia was called "Turkestan" and the Chagatay language called "Turki", even though the people only referred to themselves as "[[Mughals]]", "Sarts", "Taranchis" and "[[Tājik people|Tajiks]]". This name "Turk", was not commonly used by most groups of the [[Kipchak languages|Kypchak branch]], such as the Kazakhs, although they are closely related to the Oghuz (Turkmens) and Karluks (Karakhanids, Sarts, Uyghurs). Neither did Bulgars ([[Kazan Tatars]], [[Chuvash people|Chuvash]]) and non-Muslim Turkic groups (Tuvans, [[Yakuts]], [[Yugurs]]) come close to adopting the ethnonym "Turk" in its Islamic Era sense. Among the Karakhanid period Turkmen tribes rose the Atabeg Seljuq of the Kinik tribe, whose dynasty grew into a great Islamic empire stretching from India to Anatolia.
Turkic soldiers in the army of the [[Abbasid]] [[Caliphate|caliphs]] emerged as the ''de facto'' rulers of much of the Muslim Middle East (apart from [[Syria]] and North Africa) from the 13th century. The [[Oghuz Turks|Oghuz]] and other tribes captured and dominated various countries under the leadership of the [[Seljuk Turks|Seljuk dynasty]], and eventually captured the territories of the Abbasid dynasty and the [[Byzantine Empire]].
Meanwhile, the [[Kyrgyz people|Kyrgyz]] and Uyghurs were struggling with one another and with the Chinese Empire. The Kyrgyz people ultimately settled in the region now referred to as [[Kyrgyzstan]]. The [[Batu Khan|Batu]] hordes conquered the [[Volga Bulgars]] in what is today [[Tatarstan]] and [[Kypchaks]] in what is now Southern Russia, following the westward sweep of the [[Mongols]] in the 13th century. Other [[Bulgars]] settled in Europe in the 7-8th centuries, but were assimilated by the [[Slavs]], giving the name to the [[Bulgarians]] and the Slavic [[Bulgarian language]].
It was under [[Seljuk Sultanate of Anatolia|Seljuq suzerainty]] that numerous Turkmen tribes, especially those that came through the Caucasus via [[Azerbaijan]], acquired fiefdoms ([[beyliks]]) in newly conquered areas of [[Anatolia]], [[Iraq]] and even the [[Levant]]. Thus, the ancestors of the founding stock of the modern [[Turkish people|Turkish nation]] were most closely related to the [[Oghuz Turks|Oghuz Turkmen]] groups that settled in the Caucasus and later became the [[Azerbaijani people|Azerbaijani nation]].
By early modern times, the name "Turkestan" has several definitions: # land of sedentary Turkic-speaking townspeople that have been subjects of the Central Asian [[Chagatai people|Chagatay]]ids, i.e. [[Sart]]s, Central Asian [[Mughal Empire|Mughals]], Central Asian [[Timurid dynasty|Timurids]], [[Uyghur people|Uyghurs]] of [[Chinese Turkestan]] and the later invading [[Tatars]] that came to be known as [[Uzbeks]]; This area roughly coincides with "[[Greater Khorasan|Khorasan]]" in the widest sense, plus [[Tarim Basin]] which was known as Chinese Turkestan. It is ethnically diverse, and includes homelands of non-Turkic peoples like the [[Tājik people|Tajiks]], [[Pashtun people|Pashtuns]], [[Hazara people|Hazaras]], [[Dungan people|Dungans]], [[Dzungars]]. Turkic peoples of the Kypchak branch, i.e. Kazakhs and Kyrgyz, are not normally considered "Turkestanis" but are also populous (as pastoralists) in many parts of Turkestan. # a specific district governed by a 17th-century [[Kazakhs|Kazakh]] Khan, in modern-day [[Kazakhstan]], which were more sedentary than other Kazakh areas, and were populated by towns-dwelling Sarts

[[File:San Gregorio VA (6).jpg|thumb|right|200px|"Wild Men" depicted on the facade of the [[Colegio de San Gregorio]]]] [[File:Valladolid 258.JPG|thumb|200px|[[Iglesia de San Pablo, Valladolid|Church of San Pablo]], adjacent to Colegio de San Gregorio.]] The '''Valladolid debate''' (1550–1551) was the first moral debate in European history to discuss the rights and treatment of a [[Indigenous people of the Americas|colonized people]] by colonizers. Held in the [[Colegio de San Gregorio]], in the [[Spain|Spanish]] city of [[Valladolid]], it was a moral and theological debate about the [[European colonization of the Americas|colonization of the Americas]], its justification for the conversion to [[Catholicism]], and more specifically about the relations between the European settlers and the natives of the [[New World]]. It consisted of a number of opposing views about the way natives were to be integrated into colonial life, their conversion to Christianity, and their rights and obligations.
A controversial theologian, [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] [[Dominican friar|friar]] and Bishop of [[Chiapas]] [[Bartolomé de las Casas]], argued that the Amerindians were free men in the natural order despite their practice of [[human sacrifice]]s and other such customs, deserving the same consideration as the colonizers.<ref name="Crow, John A. 1992">Crow, John A. ''The Epic of Latin America'', 4th ed. University of California Press, Berkeley: 1992.</ref> Opposing this view were a number of scholars and priests, including humanist scholar [[Juan Ginés de Sepúlveda]], who argued that the [[human sacrifice]] of innocents, [[cannibalism]], and other such "crimes against nature" were unacceptable and should be suppressed by any means possible including war.<ref>{{cite book | title=Tratado sobre las Justas Causas de la Guerra contra los Indios | publisher=Fondo de Cultura Económica | author=Ginés de Sepúlveda, Juan (trans. Marcelino Menendez y Pelayo and Manuel Garcia-Pelayo) | year=1941 | location=Mexico D.F. | pages=155}}</ref>
Although both sides claimed to have won the [[disputation]], there is no clear record supporting either interpretation. The affair is considered one of the earliest examples of moral debates about [[colonialism]], [[human rights]] of colonized peoples, and [[international relations]]. In Spain, it served to establish Las Casas as the primary, though controversial defender of the Indians.<ref name=Wagner>{{cite book | title=The Life and Writings of Bartolomé de Las Casas | publisher=The University of New Mexico Press |author1=Raup Wagner, Henry |author2=Rand Parish, Helen |lastauthoramp=yes | year=1967 | location=New Mexico | pages=181–182}}</ref> He and others contributed to the passing of the [[New Laws]] of 1542, which limited the [[encomienda system]] further.<ref name="Hernandez">{{cite journal|author= Bonar Ludwig Hernandez|year= |title= The Las Casas-Sepúlveda Controversy: 1550-1551|journal= Ex Post Facto|volume= 10|issue= |pages= 95–104|publisher= [[San Francisco State University]]|doi= |pmid= |pmc= |url= http://userwww.sfsu.edu/~epf/journal_archive/volume_X,_2001/hernandez_b.pdf|accessdate= September 13, 2011|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150421063702/http://userwww.sfsu.edu/epf/journal_archive/volume_X%2C_2001/hernandez_b.pdf|archive-date= April 21, 2015|dead-url= yes|df= mdy-all}}</ref> Though they did not fully reverse the situation, the laws achieved considerable improvement in the treatment of Indians and consolidated their rights granted by earlier laws.<ref name="Hernandez"/> More importantly, the debate reflected a concern for morality and justice in 16th-century Spain that only surfaced in other colonial powers centuries later.
==Background== [[File:Bartolomedelascasas.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Bartolomé de las Casas]] was the principal defender of the Indians in the Junta of Valladolid]] Spain's colonization and conquest of the Americas inspired an intellectual debate especially regarding the compulsory Christianization of the Indians. [[Bartolomé de las Casas]], a [[Dominican Order|Dominican friar]] from the [[School of Salamanca]] and member of the growing [[Christian]] [[Humanism|Humanist]] movement, worked for years to oppose forced conversions and to expose the treatment of natives in the ''[[encomienda]]s''.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} His efforts influenced the [[papal bull]] ''[[Sublimis Deus]]'' of 1537 (which established the status of the Indians as rational beings).{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} More significantly, Las Casas was instrumental in the passage of the [[New Laws]] (the [[Laws of the Indies]]) of 1542, which were designed to end the encomienda system.<ref name="Hernandez"/>
Moved by Las Casas and others, in 1550 the [[King of Spain]] [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]] ordered further military expansion to cease until the issue was investigated.<ref name="Hernandez"/><ref>{{cite book | title=All Mankind is One: A study of the Disputation Between Bartolomé de Las Casas and Juan Ginés de Sepúlveda in 1550 on the Intellectual and Religious Capacity of the American Indian | publisher=Northern Illinois University Press | author=Hanke, Lewis | year=1974 | location=Illinois | pages=67}}</ref> The King assembled a ''[[jury|Junta]]'' (Jury) of eminent doctors and theologians to hear both sides and to issue a ruling on the controversy.<ref name="Crow, John A. 1992"/> Las Casas represented one side of the debate. His position found some support from the monarchy, which wanted to control the power of the encomenderos, and within the Catholic Church.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} Representing the other side was [[Juan Ginés de Sepúlveda]], whose arguments were used as support by colonists and landowners who benefited from the system.<ref name="Hernandez"/>
==Debate== [[File:Juan Ginés de Sepúlveda.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Juan Ginés de Sepúlveda]], supporter of the war "jousts" against the Indians]] Though Las Casas tried to bolster his position by recounting his experiences with the encomienda system's mistreatment of the Indians, the debate remained on largely theoretical grounds.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} Sepúlveda took a more secular approach than Las Casas, basing his arguments largely on [[Aristotle]] and the [[Humanism|Humanist]] tradition to assert that some Indians were subject to enslavement due to their inability to govern themselves, and could be subdued by war if necessary.<ref name="Crow, John A. 1992"/> Las Casas objected, arguing that Aristotle's definition of barbarian and natural slave did not apply to the Indians, all of whom were fully capable of reason and should be brought to Christianity without force or coercion.<ref name="Hernandez"/>
Sepúlveda put forward many of the arguments from his Latin dialogue ''Democrates alter sive de justi belli causis'',<ref>Anthony Padgen: ''The Fall of Natural Man: The American Indian and the Origins of Comparative Ethnology'', page 109. Cambridge University Press, 1982.</ref> to assert that the barbaric traditions of certain Indians justified waging war against them. Civilized peoples, according to Sepúlveda, were obliged to punish such vicious practices as idolatry, sodomy, and [[cannibalism]]. Wars had to be waged "in order to uproot crimes that offend nature".<ref>Juan Ginés de Sepúlveda: ''Tratado sobre las Justas Causas de la Guerra contra los Indios'', Fondo de Cultura Económica, 1941.</ref> This was an obligation to which every Spaniard, whether secular or religious, had to conform.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
Sepúlveda issued four main justifications for just war against certain Indians. First, their natural condition deemed them unable to rule themselves, and it was the responsibility of the Spaniards to act as masters. Second, Spaniards were entitled to prevent cannibalism as a crime against nature. Third, the same went for human sacrifice. Fourth, it was important to convert Indians to Christianity.<ref>{{cite book|last=Losada|first=Angel|title=Bartolome de las Casas in History: Toward an Understanding of the Man and His Work|year=1971|publisher=The Northern Illinois University Press|pages=284–289}}</ref> [[File:Codex Magliabechiano (141 cropped).jpg|thumb|200px|[[Mendoza Codex]] showing in the same drawing the kind of arguments used by both sides, advanced architecture versus brutal killings]] Las Casas was prepared for part of his opponent's discourse, since he, upon hearing about the existence of Sepúlveda's ''Democrates Alter'', had written in the late 1540s his own Latin work, the ''Apologia'', which aimed at debunking his opponent's theological arguments by arguing that Aristotle's definition of the "barbarian" and the natural slave did not apply to the Indians, who were fully capable of reason and should be brought to Christianity without force.<ref>Angel Losada: ''The Controversy between Sepúlveda and Las Casas in the Junta of Valladolid'', pages 280-282. The Northern Illinois University Press, 1971.</ref><ref>Silvio Zavala: ''Aspectos Formales de la Controversia entre Sepúlveda y Las Casas en Valladolid, a mediados del siglo XVI y observaciones sobre la apologia de Fray Bartolomé de Las Casas'', pages 137-162. Cuadernos Americanos 212, 1977.</ref>
Las Casas pointed out that every individual was obliged by international law to prevent the innocent from being treated unjustly. He also cited [[Saint Augustine]] and [[Saint John Chrysostom]], both of whom had opposed the use of force to bring others to Christian faith. Human sacrifice was wrong, but it would be better to avoid war by any means possible.<ref>Bartolomé de Las Casas, ''In Defense'', pages 212-215</ref>
The arguments presented by Las Casas and Sepúlveda to the junta of Valladolid remained abstract, with both sides clinging to their opposite theories that relied on similar, if not the same, theoretical authorities, which were interpreted to suit their respective arguments.<ref>Brading, D.A.: ''The First America: the Spanish Monarchy, Creole Patriots, and the Liberal State 1492-1867'', pages 80-88. Cambridge University Press, 1991.</ref>
==Aftermath== In the end, both parties declared that they had won the debate, but neither received the desired outcome. Las Casas saw no end to Spanish wars of conquest in the New World, and Sepúlveda did not see the New Laws' restricting of the power of the encomienda system overturned. The debate cemented Las Casas's position as the lead defender of the Indians in the Spanish Empire,<ref name=Wagner/> and further weakened the encomienda system. However, it did not substantially alter Spanish treatment of the Indians.<ref name="Hernandez"/>
==Reflection in art== In 1938 the story of the German writer [[Reinhold Schneider]] "Las Kasas and Charles V" ("Las Casas vor Karl V. Szenen aus der Konquistadorenzeit") was published.
In 1992 the Valladolid debate became an inspiration source for [[Jean-Claude Carrière]] who published the novel ''La Controverse de Valladolid'' (''Dispute in Valladolid''). The novel was filmed for television under the same name. The director — Jean-Danielle Veren, [[Jean-Pierre Marielle]] played Las Casas, [[Jean-Louis Trintignant]] acted as Sepúlveda.

[[File:Ikonnikov 1913.jpg|right]] '''Volodymyr Ikonnikov''' ({{lang-uk|Володимир Степанович Іконников}}, {{lang-ru|Владимир Степанович Иконников}}) was Ukrainian historian of the Imperial Russia specializing in study of the Russian historiography. Ikonnikov was an academician of both the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences and the [[Ukrainian Academy of Sciences]], a professor and a [[Dean (education)|dean]] of the History and Philology [[Faculty (division)|faculty]] of the [[Kiev University]].
Born in Kiev, in 1852-1861 Ikonnikov studied in Kiev Kadet School on state funds. In 1861-1865 he studied at the Kiev University History and Philology faculty at the department of Russian history. Soon after his graduation, Ikonnikov was teaching history in Kiev Military Gymnasium and history of general literature in Kiev Institute for Noble Maidens. In 1866-67 he was a [[privatdozent]] at [[Kharkiv University]]. In 1867 Ikonnikov was teaching history and philology in several gymnasiums in [[Odessa]]. Here in [[Odessa University]] in 1867 he defended his dissertation "Maksim Grek. Historical and literary research" ({{lang-ru|«Максим Грек. Историко-литературное исследование»}}) receiving a [[magister degree]] in Russian history. In 1869 he defended his doctorate dissertation at the same university "Research experience of cultural significance of Byzantium Empire in Russian History ({{lang-ru|«Опыт исследования о культурном значении Византии в русской истории»}}). After that Ikonnikov headed the department of Russian history in the Kiev University.
In 1870 he received a title of professor. In 1873-1913 Ikonnikov was an acting chief editor of "Universitetskie izvestiya" (University News) published by Kiev University. Between 1877 to 1887 he served as a [[Dean (education)|dean]] of the Kiev University History and Philology faculty. In 1874-1877 and 1893-1895 Ikonnikov was a chairman of Nestor the Chronicler Historical Society. In 1878-1889 he was a director of Kiev Higher Women Courses. In 1904 Ikonnikov was placed in charge of the Provisional Commission in research of ancient documents in Kiev.
He is a brother of the Kiev Governorate architect [[Mikhail Ikonnikov]] and a father-in-law of [[Vsevolod Petriv]].
==Important works== * "Maksim Grek. Historical and literary research" ({{lang-ru|«Максим Грек. Историко-литературное исследование»}}) Kiev, 1865–66 * "Russian public figures in the 16th century" ({{lang-ru|«Русские общественные деятели XVI в.»}}) 1866 * "Research experience of cultural significance of Byzantium Empire in Russian History ({{lang-ru|«Опыт исследования о культурном значении Византии в русской истории»}}) Kiev, 1869 * "Sceptical school in Russian historiography" ({{lang-ru|«Скептическая школа в русской историографии»}}) Kiev, 1871 ([http://dlib.rsl.ru/viewer/01003584096#?page=2 ]) * "Count N.S. Mordvinov. Historical monograph" ({{lang-ru|«Граф Н. С. Мордвинов. Историческая монография»}}) Saint Petersburg, 1873 * "Experience of Russian historiography" ({{lang-ru|«Опыт русской историографии»}}) Kiev, 1892 * "Kiev 1648-1855. Historical essay ({{lang-ru|«Киев 1648–1855. Исторический очерк»}}) 1904 * "Peasants movement in Kiev Governorate in 1826-27" ({{lang-ru|«Крестьянское движение в Киевской губернии в 1826–27 гг»}}) 1905

[[File:Yopie Prins.jpg|thumb|Yopie Prins at Big Sur, California September 2016 ]] '''Yopie Prins''' is [[Irene Butter]] Collegiate Professor of English and Comparative Literature at the [[University of Michigan]]. Her research includes [[classical reception studies|classical reception]], [[comparative literature]], [[historical poetics]], [[lyric theory]], [[translation studies]] and [[Victorian poetry]].<ref name=G/><ref name=UoM/>
Prins studied ancient Greek at Swarthmore College, and English literature at Newnham College, Cambridge. She spent a year at the University of Amsterdam as a Fulbright Scholar, before gaining a PhD in Comparative Literature from Princeton in 1991. She taught for four years at Oberlin College before joining the faculty of the University of Michigan.<ref name=personal/> Having taught at the University of Michigan since 1994, she is currently the Chair of the Department of Comparative Literature there.<ref name=UoM/> She was the vice president of the American Association for Comparative Literature from 2013 to 2015, and president from 2015 to 2016.<ref name=personal/>
Prins is married to the American composer [[Michael Daugherty]].<ref name=NYT/>
==Publications== * Prins, Yopie (2017). ''Ladies’ Greek: Victorian Translations of Tragedy''. Princeton: Princeton University Press.<ref name=G/> * Prins, Yopie (1999). ''Victorian Sappho''. Princeton: Princeton University Press.
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=G>{{citation |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/jul/07/women-classics-translation-female-scholars-translators |newspaper=The Guardian |title=Found in translation: how women are making the classics their own |date=7 July 2017 |author=Emily Wilson}}</ref> <ref name=UoM>{{citation |url=http://lsa.umich.edu/complit/people/faculty/yprins.html|access-date=15 September 2017|title=Yopie Prins: Department of Comparative Literature|publisher=University of Michigan}}</ref> <ref name=personal>{{citation|url=http://lsa.umich.edu/complit/people/faculty/yprins.html|access-date=15 September 2017|title=Yopie Prins: Home page|publisher=University of Michigan}}</ref> <ref name=NYT>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/05/14/arts/a-symphonist-of-elvis-and-barbie.html|newspaper=New York Times|title=A Symphonist of Elvis and Barbie|author=Kathryn Shattuck|date=14 May 2000}}</ref> }}

'''Île aux Basques''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] island located in the lower [[estuary]] of the [[St. Lawrence River]], about {{convert|5|km|mi}} north of [[Trois-Pistoles, Quebec|Trois-Pistoles]], in [[Les Basques Regional County Municipality]] of the [[Bas-Saint-Laurent]] region of [[Quebec]]. The island is part of the municipality of [[Notre-Dame-des-Neiges, Quebec|Notre-Dame-des-Neiges]].<ref>[http://www.toponymie.gouv.qc.ca/ct/ToposWeb/fiche.aspx?no_seq=3793 Commission de toponymie Quebec]</ref>
It is, since its acquisition by Société Provancher in 1929, a protected area as a [[Animal sanctuary|sanctuary]] for [[Bird migration|migratory bird]]s.<ref>[http://www.bonjourquebec.com/qc-en/attractions-directory/cruise-company/excursions-a-lile-aux-basques_1899812.html Excursions à l'Île aux Basques - Bonjour Québec.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> From 1584 until about 1637 it was occupied several times by the [[Basque people|Basques]], after whom the island takes its name. Both the lack of space in the [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque Country]] and the abundance of whales in the St. Lawrence River led to the arrival of the Basque fishermen to the island. The Basque Country was divided between the Crown of [[France]] and the Crown of [[Spain]] since the 1512 [[Spanish conquest of Iberian Navarre|Spanish invasion of the Kingdom of Navarre]].
A series of wars and invasions led seafarers to explore further inland from the [[Atlantic Ocean]] for seals, porpoises and whales. The Basques also practiced trade with the [[Iroquois]] and [[Algonquin people|Algonquins]], one of the first places where the legacy of these two cultures can be seen. These facts were confirmed by archaeological excavations in the 1990s at various locations on the island.
The island is home to Basque and Native American sites, four of which are situated along its southern shore.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William & Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref> These four sites, or shore camps, resemble similar sites scattered along the shores of the Gulf of St. Lawrence.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William & Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref> Shore camps not only gave fishermen and whalers a chance to replenish their supplies of firewood and fresh water, but they also provided space to dry their catch of fish.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Taylor|first1=Alan|title=American Colonies: The Settling of North America|date=2001|publisher=Penguin|location=New York|isbn=9780142002100|page=94}}</ref> Whalers also used shore camps to process whales and render the blubber into oil.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Taylor|first1=Alan|title=American Colonies: The Settling of North America|date=2001|publisher=Penguin|location=New York|isbn=9780142002100|page=94}}</ref> Four single-hearth Basque ovens used in this process have been discovered on the island; two of these ovens were found at l'Anse à la Baleine, the third and fourth at l'Anse Qui Pue and l'Anse d'En Bas, respectively.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William & Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref> In the oven at la Baleine, archaeologists discovered evidence of charred blubber and combustion, as well as pieces of terra cotta roof tiles and fragments of European crockery.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William & Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref> In addition, archaeologists found two glass beads alongside the Basque artifacts at la Baleine; one turquoise-colored and the other white, both matched descriptions of types of beads known to be traded by Europeans to native peoples.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William & Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref> Native American pottery shards and other Basque items have also been found at the other archaeological sites spread out along the southern shore, confirming that the Basques and native peoples frequented these sites at the same time.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William & Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref>
The last known documentation of Basque presence on the island was made by Jesuit Paul Lejeune in 1637.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William & Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref> Although the exact time the Basques stopped frequenting the island is unknown, the 1664 writings of another Jesuit, Father Henri Nouvel, confirm that the Basque occupation of the island bearing their name was by that time a thing of the past.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William and Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref> He observed, "It [the island] goes by the name of the Isle aux Basques, on account of the whaling which the Basques did there in bygone days. I took pleasure in visiting the large ovens they had built to make their oil, about which we can still see the great ribs of Whales they killed."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turgeon|first1=Laurier|title=French Fishers, Fur Traders, and Amerindians during the Sixteenth Century: History and Archaeology|journal=The William & Mary Quarterly, Third Series|date=October 1998|volume=55|issue=4|pages=585–610|jstor=2674446}}</ref>
The island is {{convert|2|km|mi}} long and {{convert|400|m|ft}} wide, covering an area of {{convert|0.55|km2|mi2}}. Its highest point has an elevation of {{convert|50|m|ft}} in the center of the island. It is located in the physiographic region of the [[Appalachia]], on the south bank of the St. Lawrence opposite the city of Trois-Pistoles, about {{convert|250|km|mi}} east of [[Quebec City]].
Île aux Basques was designated as a [[National Historic Site of Canada]].<ref>{{DFHD|1943|Île aux Basques|31 March 2012}}</ref>
